title: Are Certificates of Deposit exempt in Bankruptcy, Chapter 7?
question: I have 2 small CDs close to $500 set aside for my children but they are under my name. Are these exempt?
answers:
Yes, the CD"s would be exempt.

There is no specific exemption for CDs. They are no different than a bank account.

You may be able to exempt the CDs depending on what other assets you have. I'm not very familiar with CA exemptions schemes but in most states you can use a wildcard exemption to protect miscellaneous assets such as CDs. Since you have little value in the CDs it shouldn't be much of an issue anyhow. You should consult with a CA attorney to be sure. Good luck.

If you have lived in California for at least two years, you can use the wildcard exemption and exempt the CDs. California opted out of the federal exemption scheme, and uses its own. The wildcard itslef is worth $23,200. So you could exempt a lot more. Not to mention that we have exemptions for vehicles, clothing, household goods etc.

Probably a good idea to consult with counsel. Good luck.

You can probably fit them in if you use the federal exemptions. Depending upon what state you live in, you could protect them under state exemptions if they are part of a retirement plan, but not if they are simply two CD's and are in your name, then most likely the Trustee might be interested in them. Although this is not always the case, just because they may not be exempt, the Trustee might not want to go to the trouble of seizing them if they have to notify all the creditors to file their proof of claims.
